Football.title: Football‚Äôs rulemakers to launch review of VAR and plan for ‚ÄòVin√≠cius Law‚Äô
Football.content:
Football‚Äôs lawmaking authority, the Ifab, is to conduct a two-year review of the video assistant referee to ensure the technology is being used ‚Äúto its best‚Äù. The announcement on Saturday came alongside a flurry of enhancements to the rulebook before the World Cup, including expanding the use of VAR into determining corner kicks.

Another proposal could mean punishments for players obscuring their mouths being fast-tracked for implementation at this summer‚Äôs tournament, after the alleged racist abuse of Vin√≠cius J√∫nior by Benfica‚Äôs Gianluca Prestianni.

The VAR review was confirmed by the technical director of Ifab, David Elleray, on the 10th anniversary of the decision to first trial video technology. ‚ÄúWe have agreed today that after 10 years we should be reviewing VAR to see where we want to go with it in the future,‚Äù Elleray said.

‚ÄúThere is a very interesting debate over what direction VAR should go in because within football there are two contrasting philosophies: some that want as far as possible perfect decision making ‚Ä¶ and those who say we have to accept that refereeing errors are part of the game.‚Äù

Before the outcome of any review, Ifab confirmed that VAR‚Äôs powers are to be extended into three new areas. The first will give official permission to check and review any red card decision that comes from a ‚Äúclearly incorrect second yellow card‚Äù. Second, they will be able to intervene when the referee punishes the wrong team for an offence.

Finally VAR will be able to review a ‚Äúclearly incorrectly awarded corner kick‚Äù, albeit only under the condition that the review ‚Äúcan be completed immediately and without delaying the restart‚Äù.

View image in fullscreen VAR will now be able to review a ‚Äòclearly incorrectly awarded corner kick‚Äô. Photograph: Sebastian Frej/Getty Images

All of these developments are to be in place by June and it is expected that Ifab will confirm new disciplinary measures related to discriminatory behaviour too. There is to be a fast-tracked consultation over incidents where players ‚Äúcover their mouth when confronting opponents during matches‚Äù or ‚Äúunilaterally the field of play as an act of protest‚Äù as in the case of the Senegal national side during this year‚Äôs Afcon final. Both actions are likely to be punished with a yellow card.

The first ‚Äúsemi-live‚Äù trial of VAR was conducted in 2016 during a men‚Äôs international friendly between France and Italy. A decade later video technology is now embedded in the top echelons of the game but has driven widespread dissatisfaction due to delays in decision making and matches being determined by marginal outcomes.

The English FA‚Äôs chief executive, Mark Bullingham, said it was key that rulemakers continued to innovate in their application of VAR. ‚ÄúThere is a review going on looking at how we use VAR to its best,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIf you look at the innovations that Fifa have brought through, particularly in semi-autonomous offside, I think they‚Äôre fantastic.

‚ÄúThe speed with which decisions are made, and the accuracy, takes a big amount of frustration away from fans. The other interesting area is looking at what can we learn from other trials being done? The Football Video Support system gives the coach a challenge system. Are there elements of that we should consider adopting for the future? Because that reduces the amount of times when there is a VAR intervention and effectively puts the emphasis on the coach.‚Äù

At the AGM in his role as chair of the Fifa referee‚Äôs committee, Pierluigi Collina encapsulated the first decade of VAR with a metaphor. ‚ÄúIn Italy we are used to saying that, in every wonderful marriage, there is a crisis after seven years,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSo it might be possible that people fell in love with the VAR and then after some years, as with your wife, you have a small crisis.‚Äù

View image in fullscreen Fifa referee‚Äôs committee, Pierluigi Collina, spoke at the AGM. Photograph: David Davies/PA

In addition to the extension of VAR protocols, the Ifab brought in new measures to tackle time-wasting and the disruption of tempo in matches. The successful introduction of the eight-second rule for goalkeepers has encouraged Ifab to go further on efforts to stop players slowing the game.

Referees will be given the power to start a five-second countdown if they feel players are taking too long over throw-ins and dead-ball goal kicks, with the throw-in reversed or a corner kick the sanction for delaying. Substitutions must be completed in no more than 10 seconds, otherwise the substitute must stay off for at least one minute.

Football.title: ‚ÄòWe missed him‚Äô: Xhaka adds steel as Sunderland share point at Bournemouth
Football.content:
For those Sunderland fans making the 700-mile round trip from Wearside, some beginning their journey at midnight, they arrived to the welcome sight of Granit Xhaka‚Äôs first start since 17 January. Could the captain‚Äôs return inspire Sunderland from the slump that began in mid-December? On the south coast, a losing run came to its end. R√©gis Le Bris‚Äôs team claimed the point their determined performance deserved.

‚ÄúTo have a natural leader like that come into the team is great,‚Äù said the Sunderland defender Dan Ballard. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve missed him.‚Äù Patrolling in front of defence, Xhaka maintained constant dialogue with his colleagues, encouraging, directing into position, veering into the territory of player-manager. ‚ÄúAfter three defeats it‚Äôs not easy to react and for a newly promoted side, confidence is always a topic,‚Äù said Le Bris. ‚ÄúI am happy with the team spirit.‚Äù

When Eliezer Mayenda scored Sunderland‚Äôs goal, Xhaka clenched his fists in triumph, celebrating first with Le Bris. For Bournemouth, for whom a draw dents outside hopes of European football next season, a wholly preventable goal. Habib Diarra had been shown inside from Ballard‚Äôs pass. Their goalkeeper, Djordje Petrovic, could only direct Diarra‚Äôs shot into Mayenda‚Äôs path.

Bournemouth have not lost since 3 January but struggle to kill off their opponents; this was a 12th draw of the season. The goalless draw at West Ham had forced a rethink, Evanilson benched. ‚ÄúI was looking to match their midfield because they have very good players in the middle,‚Äù explained Andoni Iraola. That plan was torn up at half-time, the Brazilian scored the equaliser, Iraola‚Äôs in-game management coming up trumps. ‚ÄúWe know the first half wasn‚Äôt ourselves,‚Äù said Bournemouth‚Äôs Marcus Tavernier. ‚ÄúIn the second half we knew we needed a reaction.‚Äù

Sunderland did not start like a team in the doldrums. Noah Sadiki‚Äôs shot forced an early save from Petrovic and when Enzo Le F√©e was floored by √Ålex Jim√©nez, a penalty looked like a credible claim. And yet Jarred Gillett, the referee, waved that away, his judgment of ‚Äúnormal contact‚Äù backed by video assistance, to the incredulity of Le F√©e who said ruefully: ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt change the decision now.‚Äù Iraola‚Äôs view: ‚ÄúIt would have been a soft one.‚Äù

Wearside muscle took a stronghold in those early stages, their twin towers, Ballard and Omar Alderete, overpowered Eli Junior Kroupi while Trai Hume did a decent job of keeping Rayan quiet until the game‚Äôs dying embers.

View image in fullscreen Eliezer Mayenda gives Sunderland the lead. Photograph: Graham Hunt/ProSports/Shutterstock

Another goalkeeping error almost let Bournemouth back in, only for Robin Roefs to recover after he had dropped a Tavernier shot. Roefs got luckier yet when, out of his penalty area, he lost possession and collided with Kroupi. That decision went Sunderland‚Äôs way, to audible disgust from Iraola, wanting a straight red, though he afterwards said Gillett should have let play go on, which would probably have resulted in a goal. Roefs, otherwise excellent, would have been a profound loss.

Xhaka was at the centre of a second-half flashpoint when he and Tyler Adams crunched together, the American clattering his opponent‚Äôs ankle. ‚ÄúReally dangerous,‚Äù said Le Bris. Adams escaped a red on the video verdict, though was quickly removed by Iraola as a sending off waiting to happen. To compound the confusion, Gillett had also awarded a Bournemouth free-kick. On came Ryan Christie, his first touch supplying Tavernier for a cross that evaded Sunderland‚Äôs defenders, the ball knocked in by Evanilson‚Äôs shoulder. ‚ÄúThe gaffer pointed out that we had to put in balls early,‚Äù said Tavernier.

View image in fullscreen Evanilson shoulders the ball home after a great cross from Marcus Tavernier. Photograph: Ian Walton/Reuters

Roefs‚Äô booking for time-wasting marked the shift in momentum towards Bournemouth. Xhaka‚Äôs departure in the 76th minute left his teammates to see out a result, part of the plan according to his manager. ‚ÄúAt the end our togetherness was strong,‚Äù said Le Bris. Without Xhaka, Sunderland had the ball in the net but when Ballard bundled home Lutsharel Geertruida had strayed offside.

The chase for a winner became frantic, fiery when Christie and Le F√©e went up in each other‚Äôs grill while both sets of fans were united in railing at Gillett. Rayan at last found space in fully 12 minutes of time added on and a rasping shot from the flank deflecting off Alderete and behind had the home support gasping in expectation for a goal that never arrived.

Football.title: Championship roundup: Norwich compound struggling Leicester‚Äôs home woes
Football.content:
Norwich condemned relegation-threatened Leicester to a fourth successive home Championship defeat to end Gary Rowett‚Äôs unbeaten start as manager.

The second-half substitute Anis Ben Slimane drilled Norwich ahead just six minutes after coming off the bench at the King Power Stadium before Ali Ahmed‚Äôs close-range finish sealed a seventh win in nine league games.

The result extended Leicester‚Äôs winless league run to nine matches and kept them third-bottom but further strengthened Norwich‚Äôs bid for survival as Philippe Clement‚Äôs in-form side climbed 11 points clear of the drop zone.

Rowett had seen his side claim creditable away draws in his first two games since taking charge and they started brightly enough, with Ricardo Pereira almost sending Bobby De Cordova-Reid clear, only for his through-ball to hit the midfielder‚Äôs heel.

With former head coach Enzo Maresca watching from the stands, Leicester‚Äôs final ball lacked quality and composure, summed up when Harry Winks overhit a diagonal pass, aimed for Luke Thomas, straight out of play.

Slimane came on for the dangerous Paris Maghoma just after the hour and within minutes forced a brilliant save from Jakub Stolarczyk after Ben Chrisene‚Äôs cross had deflected into his path.

But there was nothing the Leicester goalkeeper could do to stop his next effort as Slimane combined with Sam Field on the edge of the area and drilled a fine shot into the bottom left-hand corner after 68 minutes.

The goal extended Leicester‚Äôs run without a clean sheet to 29 games and worse was to follow nine minutes later. Kellen Fisher was allowed time and space from a set piece by a dozing defence to advance and cross, with Stolarczyk deflecting Errol Mundle-Smith‚Äôs shot across goal to the back post where an unmarked Ahmed poked home.

Matt Crooks‚Äô smash-and-grab goal secured Hull a 1-0 victory at Portsmouth to match a 60-year record. The Tigers only had two shots but made them count as Crooks capitalised on a defensive mix-up to make it five away wins in a row; the last time Hull had won as many on the road was 1966.

It also made sure they kept the pressure on the top two in the automatic promotion race, while Pompey lost back-to-back home matches for just the third time since their return to the second tier.

The Tigers came out of the traps quickly and should have opened the scoring after 44 seconds. Lewis Koumas got down the left side and sent a low ball in the box for Joe Gelhardt, but he fired straight at Nicolas Schmid. Oli McBurnie headed the rebound home but was flagged offside.

From then on in the first half, Pompey had 69% of the possession and all 14 of the other shots in the half. Then, out of nowhere in the second half, the Tigers took the lead, as Crooks was gifted a tap-in after a double Adrian Segecic error.

The Australian‚Äôs miscontrol put him in danger before a short backpass allowed McBurnie to close down keeper Schmid and the ball popped up for Crooks to lash home for his fourth goal of the season.

View image in fullscreen Derby‚Äôs Ben Brereton D√≠az wheels away after scoring his side‚Äôs first goal against Blackburn. Photograph: Nigel French/PA

Derby revived their playoff challenge with an impressive second-half comeback to beat Blackburn 3-1 at Pride Park. The visitors led through Hayden Carter‚Äôs header but Ben Brereton D√≠az struck against his former club to turn the game in Derby‚Äôs favour.

Matt Clarke punished tentative defending before the impressive Derry Murkin claimed his second assist to provide Rhian Brewster with the goal to seal victory and leave Rovers in relegation trouble.

On Friday, Jeremy Ngakia‚Äôs 77th-minute strike secured a 2-1 win for Watford over Bristol City at Ashton Gate. The visitors took a seventh-minute lead when Luca Kjerrumgaard fired home from six yards. But the home side were level in the 36th minute when Scott Twine powered a close-range header past Egil Selvik.

A draw looked the likely outcome, but Ngakia found the top corner with a sweetly struck right-foot shot from 25 yards out.

Football.title: Igor Tudor accuses ‚Äòfatigued‚Äô Tottenham squad of lacking fitness and desire
Football.content:
Igor Tudor says his Tottenham players are not fit enough and has questioned their desire to put in the hard yards without the ball.

The interim head coach has a clearer idea of the problems he faces after two weeks ‚Äì and there are many of them, including low levels of confidence and the capacity of the younger players to handle the pressure of a relegation battle.

Tudor knows there are reasons for the physical issues with the squad stretched by an injury crisis amid a punishing schedule. Although Pedro Porro and Kevin Danso are in contention to return for Sunday‚Äôs trip to Fulham, Tottenham will be without eight injured players plus the suspended Cristian Romero.

Tudor believes there is only one way out of the situation ‚Äì an on-the-hoof fitness reboot in training, particularly as the club had no midweek fixture last week or this. The Croat surprised the players by working them extremely hard throughout last week and not tapering off before last Sunday‚Äôs home game against Arsenal, which they lost 4-1. As Tudor made plain, it is not a time to pander to player sensibilities.

‚ÄúPhysically, we are not in an amazing situation,‚Äù Tudor said. ‚ÄúThey have played lots of games in the last period without lots of players available and it made the physical condition of the team drop down. So we need to use this period where we don‚Äôt play the games to put some petrol in the engine so the engine starts to work better.

‚ÄúThey are fatigued. To do the pressing high you need to be fit. But [it is] all of them because if someone is not in the right shape there is a problem because someone is coming late [to the press].

‚ÄúThe second thing is that there is the other goal to protect. It is easy to run there but you need to run back. If you run up and don‚Äôt run back it‚Äôs a problem. For sure, we will improve and do these things better over time but in this moment it‚Äôs a big question what we can do and what we cannot do.‚Äù

Tudor was asked about his full-throttle approach from the first training session. ‚ÄúYes, that‚Äôs the only way ‚Äì running,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe pitch is 100 yards, it‚Äôs long. So you need to run.

‚ÄúMaybe you have habits to, I don‚Äôt know ‚Ä¶ work a bit less. I put some runs without the ball [into the sessions]. Never players like runs without the ball so we put some runs without balls. But it‚Äôs a moment when there is no time to think too much about what somebody doesn‚Äôt like. And the best thing is that they understand this. They gave me their availability to do these things.‚Äù

Tudor is under no illusions about the size of the challenge. It was put to him that the striker, Randal Kolo Muani, had played well against Arsenal. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs good, one good thing,‚Äù he replied.

What Tudor wants to see at Fulham and beyond is players such as Kolo Muani stepping up, accepting the responsibility. ‚ÄúSome players are still young,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThey were brought here to help and now maybe they are in a moment where they need to resolve the problems.

View image in fullscreen Randal Kolo Muani scores against Arsenal ‚Äì Igor Tudor wants him to keep raising his game for Spurs. Photograph: David Klein/Reuters

‚ÄúIf you have too many of these players because of the amount of injuries, who are playing together in the squad, it does create some problems. But it is also an opportunity and a challenge to grow fast, to become a man. To say: ‚ÄòCome on, I‚Äôm the guy, give me the ball, I will score.‚Äô Instead of just: ‚ÄòWhat can I do? I‚Äôm just here, you know.‚Äô

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs always how you see the situation. It‚Äôs not: ‚ÄòI‚Äôm just here. We had 15 players and I was always left out and now we have 10 players out, so I play.‚Äô How do you really see that situation? If you are the right guy and positive, there is opportunity.‚Äù

Tudor has not dwelt for long on the derby with Arsenal. ‚ÄúNo, no, forget that,‚Äù he said. It was never likely to be a game that would define the club‚Äôs survival hopes. The same is not true of Fulham ‚Äì or the home fixture against Crystal Palace next Thursday.

‚ÄúAfter the first game, I said if you play against the best team in the world at this moment, it‚Äôs not a realistic game to show [whether] we are soldiers or we are not soldiers,‚Äù Tudor said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the truth. They show they can be in some parts of the game. But for long periods we had problems, in defence especially. It‚Äôs not easy against them. Let‚Äôs see in the next games.‚Äù

Football.title: Arsenal are easy targets for TikTok mockery ‚Äì they must not be prisoners of that narrative | David Hytner
Football.content:
Arsenal had to expect the jibes from Tottenham and they were not disappointed. Just before kick-off in last Sunday‚Äôs north London derby, the Spurs support in the South Stand of their stadium spelled out a giant message in mosaic form. ‚ÄúNorth Ldn since 1882,‚Äù it read.

A clear dig, then, at Arsenal‚Äôs south of the river history from the Woolwich days and, as mentioned, very much a part of a rivalry where goading and baiting go hand in hand with the loathing. Arsenal had been similarly provocative before the derby against Spurs at the Emirates Stadium last November, lighting the pre-match scene with a tifo featuring images of various club greats. The most prominent at the top of it? Sol Campbell, of course.

What was more surprising ‚Äì and certainly led to raised eyebrows at Arsenal ‚Äì was Wolves‚Äô now infamous TikTok post on the Thursday before last. The 80-second clip, uploaded after the 2-2 draw between the clubs the previous night, was a savage take on Arsenal‚Äôs ‚Äúgame management‚Äù. Or, to put it another way, and as Wolves surely intended, their dark arts and shithousery.

The social media team at Wolves showed how Gabriel Martinelli taunted the home crowd by flashing up the scoreline on his fingers as Arsenal led 2-1. They highlighted the delay in Arsenal taking a corner as they continued to lead. They mocked Gabriel Magalh√£es for going down after an apparent head clash before he got back up and carried on.

There was indignation from the in-house commentators when Leandro Trossard also went to ground after an aerial clash in the 90th minute. In the background, it was easy to make out the chant from the Wolves fans: ‚ÄúSame old Arsenal, always cheating.‚Äù There was laughter and the corresponding emojis on the clip when Wolves equalised at the bitter end.

There was more from elsewhere later in the day. At tea time, Manchester City‚Äôs X account piped up with a three-year-old clip of their team playing keep-ball by the corner flag in the dying minutes of a 2-0 home victory over Newcastle. ‚ÄúSeeing out the win,‚Äù read the text with a tick emoji above footage of Erling Haaland and Jack Grealish, well, managing the game to a successful conclusion. It was a mickey-take with an obvious target.

This is where Arsenal find themselves as they prepare for Sunday‚Äôs home game against Chelsea ‚Äì the latest staging post in their draining push for the Premier League title. Their rivals, big and small, are lining up the pot shots, eager to have fun at their expense, to prey on their sensitivities. To drive a particular narrative and make Arsenal prisoners of it.

The Wolves TikTok clip overlooked a major detail when it came to Trossard. On as a 73rd-minute substitute, the winger was cleaned out by a shoulder barge from Santiago Bueno, who was on a yellow card. Trossard had eyes only for the high ball; the Wolves defender looked directly at him and left a calling card on his opponent‚Äôs jaw. A dazed Trossard was forced off after treatment, Arsenal relieved that he avoided injury, and how do you think the club‚Äôs doctors felt about essentially being accused of complicity in a plot to run down the clock?

Nobody thought about that. They were too busy enjoying the clip, which went viral for the reason that these things always do. It struck a chord. It fed a perception with which opposing fans are seemingly on board. Arsenal as the roughhouse guys ‚Äì and not only when they are loading men into the six-yard box on corners. The ones that will do whatever it takes to win.

View image in fullscreen Leandro Trossard‚Äôs injury at Wolves seemed to invoke opprobrium from the home side. Photograph: Jacob King/PA

Arsenal were much better than Spurs. They deserved to beat them, which they did; to clear their heads after the trauma of Wolves. As an aside, it was only this Spurs team. Chelsea ought to be a tougher prospect. Yet Arsenal did get away with one in the 53rd minute as they led 2-1. Would it have been different if Randal Kolo Muani had not been penalised for the slightest of pushes into Gabriel‚Äôs back before he shot past David Raya? At the very least, Arsenal would have felt their anxiety levels rise.

Gabriel drew the contact to the referee‚Äôs attention in theatrical fashion, as he had done at Newcastle last September in a similar situation against Nick Woltemade. That day, the referee said no foul and Woltemade scored. This time, Gabriel got the decision.

What did Gabriel do after the game? Did he a) keep his head down and quietly count his blessings? Or b) post a picture to social media of him holding a hand of cards with the four of hearts visible, signifying his team‚Äôs four goals? He went for the latter, even tagging the Spurs forward Richarlison. Cue a host of diving memes in the responses. Was goading really the right option given the climate around the club? On the other hand, you have to admire Gabriel‚Äôs chutzpah.

Mikel Arteta‚Äôs response to what we are obliged to call the ‚Äúoutside noise‚Äù has been to narrow the focus; to dial up the intensity while also talking up his players and their mindset. The manager has his eyes on the prize and there are a number of points that need to be made, beginning with the feeling towards him and his side in coaching circles.

Towards the end of January, Pep Guardiola described Arsenal as the ‚Äúbest team in the world‚Äù and it did not sound like just mind games from the City manager. The Wolves head coach, Rob Edwards, messaged Arteta after last week‚Äôs game to say that Arsenal were the best side in the league and there have been others in their positions who have privately expressed the highest admiration for what Arteta is doing. Namely, how Arsenal press, massing men around the ball, cutting off the passing lanes, forcing turnovers. How they dominate in possession, playing on the front foot, creating overloads, moving it quickly. The watchwords are remorselessness and control.

According to Opta, Arsenal have had seven yellow cards for time-wasting in the league this season ‚Äì the same number as Chelsea and behind only Bournemouth and Fulham, who each have eight. They are the seventh-worst offenders for the average time of delays for restarts, taking in set pieces and goal-kicks. They sit behind Sunderland, Brentford, Crystal Palace, Newcastle, Leeds and Burnley on the list in that order.

Arteta and his players remain at the centre of a storm, buffeted by ill winds, Chelsea ready to bring the latest of them. If Arsenal hold their nerve, they will have done it the hard way.

Football.title: Chelsea‚Äôs Chloe Sarwie: ‚ÄòI‚Äôm expressing myself but my full self hasn‚Äôt come out yet‚Äô
Football.content:
‚ÄúI just want to have my name out there to the point where when someone hears it they know instantly who is being talked about,‚Äù says the Chelsea full-back Chloe Sarwie. ‚ÄúI want to be that player who can amaze people constantly and that is up there as one of the best.‚Äù

You could be forgiven for viewing this level of confidence as arrogant, but you would be wrong. The talented 17-year-old defender comes across as grounded, intelligent, hard-working and humble, but her edge is a steely belief in her football.

Sarwie is speaking to the Guardian shortly before signing her first professional contract, four months after her debut in the 1-1 draw with Twente in the Champions League and three months after her first call-up to the England Under-23s.

Sarwie is back with the under‚Äë23s for next month‚Äôs games against France and the Netherlands, one of two 17-year-olds considered good enough to compete alongside those vying for a chance in the senior side (the other is Erica Meg Parkinson, who plays her club football in Portugal). Last summer, at 16, she was in the squad that competed at the Under-19 Euros in Poland. ‚ÄúI was taken aback and I didn‚Äôt really have any expectations so it was incredible,‚Äù she says.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs honestly a really intense environment and every training session everyone just wants to one-up each other. It gets really competitive and just being around that wanting-to-win group was incredible.‚Äù

Her Chelsea debut in October, when still 16, came as a surprise. ‚ÄúAs soon as I got the nod from Sonia [Bompastor] that I‚Äôd be coming on for Sandy [Baltimore] and making my debut, I was just down on the sideline, shocked but pumped and ready to get on the pitch,‚Äù says Sarwie, who entered the fray against Twente in the 73rd minute.

She impressed instantly, playing with an admirable fearlessness. ‚ÄúHonestly, when I stepped on that pitch, I didn‚Äôt know what to do, I didn‚Äôt know how to play, but I was just trying to play my part for the team, fit in and see what I could do. Towards the end of the game, I was being myself a bit more and the more playing time I‚Äôm getting, the more I‚Äôm able to express myself, but my full self hasn‚Äôt come out yet.‚Äù

View image in fullscreen Chloe Sarwie (right) made her Chelsea debut in the Champions League draw with Twente last October. Photograph: Chris Lee/Chelsea FC/Getty Images

Chelsea are well equipped at right-back, with two of the world‚Äôs best in Lucy Bronze and Ellie Carpenter at their disposal, but at left-back there is a hole. With Baltimore performing well in the position but naturally a more attacking player and Niamh Charles out with an ankle injury, there have been some opportunities for Sarwie, against Crystal Palace in the FA Cup and West Ham and Tottenham in the Women‚Äôs Super League.

Should her development continue at its accelerated pace there is also the chance to stake a claim in the senior England squad that has had question marks at left‚Äëback under Sarina Wiegman. London City Lionesses‚Äô Poppy Pattinson is the latest to receive a call-up with an eye on finding a solution to the conundrum.

Sarwie was introduced to the Chelsea senior side in pre-season. It was ‚Äúquite exciting but also quite nerve-racking‚Äù, though training and playing with the first team has been hugely beneficial. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a great challenge and I love being challenged and going up against these players, seeing how their level compares to mine and how I can get to that level,‚Äù says Sarwie.

‚ÄúObviously, Lucy‚Äôs at England as well and being able to have that connection is great, even though I‚Äôm in one of the lower age groups because, ultimately, I‚Äôm learning how I can then progress to that next step and be part of the senior squad. That‚Äôs where she can give me tips and show what it takes.‚Äù

Sarwie began playing football in the park on her own, light on her feet thanks to ballet from the ages of two until eight. ‚ÄúI used to turn up to ballet with muddy tights after playing football and rolling around in the mud for a good hour or two. But ballet had a big impact on my journey as a football player as my dribbling playing style kind of links back to it. Ballet made me light on my feet. I also had to adapt from a ballet mindset, from a solo stage, to a football mindset and a team performance stage.‚Äù

It was in the park where coaches would approach her and tell her she should be playing for a club and eventually she thought: ‚ÄúWhy not?‚Äù After a season at Millwall, she had trials at Arsenal and Chelsea and had offers from both. ‚ÄúI had to pick Chelsea because it was closer,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI let my family down on that one because they‚Äôre all Arsenal supporters, but oh well.‚Äù

She juggles playing and training with studying for her BTec in engineering and her mum, Jean, who is a teacher at her school, is the force that has enabled her to pursue football. She takes her laptop everywhere, to catch up with coursework, with one day a week spent in the classroom.

View image in fullscreen Sarwie takes a selfie with fans after featuring in the FA Cup against Crystal Palace. Photograph: Sport Press Photo/Alamy

Sarwie is having to contend with an influx of information. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs mad trying to switch the brain from studying engineering to football and back,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm still taking in everything in relation to the first team. I have all that information coming at me and then I have to go home, switch off and then do my work and it‚Äôs all a bit chaotic.‚Äù

On the pitch, there is also a balance to be struck between what is being asked of her and instinct. ‚ÄúSometimes on the pitch I can be quite hesitant because I‚Äôm trying to think about what I should do at that moment instead of what I want to do, because that‚Äôs sometimes two different things. The coach wants me to do something but I want to do something else in the moment and it‚Äôs about quickly processing which one I should do.

‚ÄúEvery day I‚Äôm getting new information coming in and I‚Äôm just trying to soak that up but trying to show myself on the pitch and putting those words into actions on the pitch can be quite difficult and it‚Äôs going to be like that for a while because of my age.

View image in fullscreen Sarwie practised ballet until the age of eight. ‚ÄòIt made me light on my feet,‚Äô she says. Photograph: Harriet Lander/Chelsea FC/Getty Images

‚ÄúOnce I‚Äôm on the pitch I just want to be my most relaxed self. Breathing techniques on the pitch really help me stay calm and I‚Äôve been told I look arrogant doing this, but chewing gum on the pitch makes me relax as well.

‚ÄúI want to be that person that looks in place and calm with the rest of the team, that calms that team down. I don‚Äôt want to be nervous when I get the ball, or for them to be nervous when I get the ball, I want to get the ball and to express myself as much as possible with it.‚Äù

Football.title: KSI explains why Luke Littler is blocked from playing in Sidemen Charity Match
Football.content:
KSI explains why Luke Littler is blocked from playing in Sidemen Charity Match

Luke Littler has had his request to play in the Sidemen Charity Match denied - with KSI explaining why he will never be able to feature.

The blockbuster meeting of YouTubers, content creators and influencers is fast approaching, with the 2026 edition set to take place on April 18.

5 YouTube Allstars won the 2025 Sidemen Charity Match Credit: Instagram @sidemen

It has become an unmissable fixture for fans of the social media contingent, with last year's match attracting a sell-out crowd.

The group of seven YouTubers, including boxer and rapper KSI, played out an 18-goal thriller at the Home of Football in 2025, which was by the YouTube Allstars.

There was no shortage of household names on show last time out, with AngryGinge, IShowSpeed, Logan Paul and Mr Beast all featuring.

With this year's star-studded line-up yet to be confirmed, there was an early contender for the headline act.

Darts superstar Littler openly expressed his desire to take part in the Sidemen Match.

At the start of February, he shared an Instagram post by Sidemen, confirming to their 6.2 million followers that tickets for the clash were sold out within hours of going on sale.

Tagging the internet sensations, the 19-year-old wrote: "Get me in the team Sidemen."

Content creators only

After Littler's call-out left many hopeful we could see him grace the Wembley turf, KSI has now shut down the possibility.

In an appearance on Capital FM, the online personality was asked if he had responded to the teenager's plea.

"I have not responded, and he's not in," replied KSI.

5 World darts champion Littler fancied his chances of getting some minutes at Wembley Credit: Shutterstock Editorial

5 But KSI grinned as he revealed fans won't be seeing 'The Nuke' at Wembley in April Credit: Capital

And he revealed this was due to one rule, with the match operating a strict content creators-only policy.

Explaining his brutal response, KSI continued: "It sounds so bad, but we only have content creators on the Sidemen Charity Match.

"So we haven't ever had a celebrity come on to play. That's more for like Soccer Aid.

"You never know, maybe one day we'll have Soccer Aid versus Sidemen."

KSI was quick to add that Littler's snub was nothing personal, insisting that no A-listers are allowed to feature.

He added: "I think for us we're focusing more on just content creators.

5 The Sidemen Charity Match has become an eagerly-anticipated event in recent years Credit: Sidemen

"That's how it's always been, and even if Justin Bieber wanted to play, we'd go 'No! Content creators only!"

When is the 2026 Sidemen Charity Match?

The 2026 Sidemen Charity Match will take place on Saturday, April 18.

Kick-off at a sold-out Wembley Stadium is scheduled for 3pm.

It will be broadcast live on the Sidemen's YouTube channel.

The SideMen will take on the YouTube Allstars, with the fixture raising money for Bright Side and M7 Education.

Who is playing in the Sidemen Charity Match?

With a Littler appearance ruled out, it remains to be seen which online stars will take to the field at Wembley.

5 KSI will be lining up against his YouTube contingent this year Credit: Alamy

While the full cast of influencers and creators taking part has not yet been revealed, some names have already been confirmed.

All seven members of Sidemen will be on the pitch, but they won't all be on the same side side this year.

The 2026 edition will mark the first time the Sidemen are divided into separate teams, with KSI, Miniminter and Behzinga set to play for the YouTube Allstars.

Football.title: Premier League sent warning over new streaming service by financial expert
Football.content:
Premier League sent warning over new streaming service by financial expert

Premier League clubs have been issued a stark warning ahead of potential plans to launch a global digital broadcasting channel.

Chief executive Richard Masters this week revealed plans for a 24-hour a day service in Singapore.

3 Premier League chief Richard Masters has announced the launch of a 24/7 channel to be broadcast in Singapore Credit: Getty Images - Getty

The news has reignited plans for a similar system in the UK which could eventually culminate in the end of the 3pm blackout.



Fan frustration

It comes amid frustration over the rising cost of televised football with fans having to pay for multiple subscriptions to stay across the action.

With broadcast rights packages continuing to soar, subscriptions have also risen.

Premier League fans splash out for Sky Sports and TNT Sports to get their fix while fans of teams competing in the Champions league will need an Amazon Prime subscription to have complete coverage.

With the current broadcast deal ending in 2029, football finance expert Kieran Maguire believes the move to broadcast as a 24/7 channel in Singapore is a testing ground for a future shift in strategy.



‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs the Premier League dipping their toe in the water as far as its ability to take total control,‚Äù he told talkSPORT.

‚ÄúAt present, I think they‚Äôre fully aware that they are having to go via a wholesaler through their broadcast partners.



‚ÄúThe Premier League would potentially have under this system the ability to deliver Premier League-only content 24/7 and also to appeal directly to fans and to come up with a pricing mechanism which could be more palatable for fans.

‚ÄúThat could have a positive impact if it reduces the amount of piracy."



Maguire continued: ‚ÄúWhat we‚Äôve seen with the attempts of a domestic coup of the game in project big picture and the Super League which was a European coup, under both of those schemes the clubs would have been able to sell their own rights directly to fans.

3 Fans have been left angered by the rising cost of football subscriptions Credit: Getty

‚ÄúYou‚Äôd have a Real Madrid, Barcelona, Manchester United and Liverpool channel.

‚ÄúThese clubs with huge fanbases would very much like that."

No room for error

Maguire has warned clubs that while a switch to a streaming service may put the power in their hands, there will be an even greater need for solid financial management without the guarantee of set broadcasting income made known in advance.

‚ÄúThe downside for the Premier League is if you‚Äôve seen what‚Äôs happened in France, the French TV deal collapsed and the French Football Association took over (the launch of an in-house streaming service) and that‚Äôs resulted in the total monies coming through to clubs halving," he added.



‚ÄúI think the Premier League is trying to jump in between that opportunity to say look if we do it on a Premier League basis as whole, that means we will still have a fairly decent distribution of money within the Premier League and that means that we‚Äôve still got the competitive balance that is so important to the balance.

‚ÄúThe good thing about the relationships with the Premier League and the likes of Sky and Discovery + is that they‚Äôve got a degree of certainty.

3 Kieran Maguire explained the financial drawbacks of a streaming service Credit: Getty

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre trying to sign a player for 50 or 60 million pounds and you‚Äôre paying them ¬£220,000 a week on a five-year contract, if you know exactly how much money you're getting from the TV deal for the next five years, that‚Äôs going to help you budget.

Richard Keys immediately taken off air as explosions disrupt football broadcast

Richard Keys was abruptly taken off air following the United States‚Äô and Israel‚Äôs bombing of Iran.

3 Richard Keys was taken off air after US missile strikes on Iran Credit: X / beINSPORTS_EN

Keys took to X to reassure fans of his safety, writing: ‚ÄúThank you all for your messages. It was a bit lively earlier. I don‚Äôt have space to express my feelings about that idiot Trump. No show today.

Middle East on alert

Tensions escalated in the Middle East after the United States and Israel launched a joint offensive on Iran.

Missiles struck the capital Tehran while Iranian forces retaliated with strikes on Israel and other parts of the Gulf region.

The bombing got underway in Iran at 9.40am local time on Saturday morning with multiple cities having reported hearing loud explosions.

US President Donald Trump confirmed the attacks, describing them as necessary to ‚Äòeliminate imminent threats from the Iranian regime.‚Äô

A senior Iranian official told Reuters that the country would ‚Äòtake revenge‚Äô and deliver a ‚Äòstrong response.‚Äô

A controversial past

Football.title: PSG spark uproar with request before Champions League clash against Chelsea
Football.content:
Paris Saint-Germain's request to postpone a Ligue 1 fixture sandwiched between their Champions League double header with Chelsea, has been granted.

PSG and Chelsea face a repeat of last summer‚Äôs Club World Cup final in next month‚Äôs eagerly-awaited Champions League round of 16.

4 Cole Palmer stole the show when Chelsea swept aside PSG 3-0 in the club World Cup final Credit: Getty

The reigning holders, who sneaked through with a 5-4 aggregate win over Monaco in midweek, are already plotting favourable conditions ahead of the double header against Chelsea.



Gaining an advantage

On Friday, the French giants asked Ligue 1‚Äôs governing body ‚Äì the Ligue de Football Professionnel (LFP) ‚Äì to postpone their match against relegation-threatened Nantes set for March 14 to allow for extra days of rest between the two fixtures.

PSG will host Liam Rosenior‚Äôs men on Wednesday, March 11 with the return leg taking place at Stamford Bridge on Tuesday, March 17.

Chelsea, meanwhile, host Newcastle in a crucial clash in the battle for the top four on Saturday, March 14 at 5.30pm.

On Friday, the LFP released their match schedule for week 26 in France‚Äôs top-flight but confirmed just eight of the nine matches that weekend.



The LFP subsequently revealed that it had been approached by PSG for the game to be postponed until week commencing April 20, 'in order to prepare in the best possible conditions for their two-legged tie with Chelsea in the Champions League'.

The governing body also confirmed that Nantes had given their agreement to the postponement.



A LFP statement on Saturday confirmed that PSG's request had been granted.

It read: "At the request of Paris Saint-Germain in order to prepare in the best possible conditions for its two-legged tie with Chelsea in the Champions League Round of 16, the LFP Board of Directors, with the agreement of FC Nantes, has decided that the PSG - FC Nantes match will be played the week of April 20.



"The exact date and time of this match will be determined later."

4 A tired-looking PSG edged past Monaco in midweek to book their spot in the last 16 Credit: AFP

The decision has already caused uproar from fans on both sides of the English Channel.

France‚Äôs other European representatives Lyon, Strasbourg and Lille have not requested similar changes, while the Premier League have not historically moved fixtures to accommodate European competition.

PSG are hoping the move will ease fatigue and injury issues that have swept through their squad this season.

With 103 matches played in the past 18 months and just two weeks rest during the summer, Les Parisiens are yet to recapture the level that took them to Champions League glory last term.



Ligue 1's provisions

It is not the first time that Ligue 1 chiefs have shifted domestic fixtures to support its teams on the European stage.

With Ligue 1's financial situation in disarray owing in-part to the league's nominal television broadcast deal, protecting its UEFA coefficient while boosting its club's chances in Europe has become a priority.

4 PSG were afforded the same fixture luxury against Aston Villa but still ended up slipping to a 3-2 defeat on the night Credit: Getty

4 Luis Enrique is eagerly awaiting the double header against Chelsea next month Credit: Getty

PSG were the beneficiaries of a fixture change in last season‚Äôs run to Champions League glory.



In between, their quarter-final double header against Aston Villa, their match against Nantes was postponed until the following week despite Les Canari‚Äôs opposing the change.

In the 2023/24 season, their Ligue 1 fixture at Nice scheduled between two Champions League semi-final ties with Borussia Dortmund was also moved to a later date.

Ironically, PSG are yet to see any benefit of postponing fixtures between European ties.

Luis Enrique‚Äôs men were beaten 3-2 at Villa Park despite advancing on aggregate, while slipping to a 1-0 defeat in the second leg against Dortmund.

The PSG boss says he is looking forward to facing Chelsea after avoiding another meeting with former club Barcelona.



‚ÄúThe Champions League draw is difficult, as usual. We don‚Äôt expect anything different,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe are pleased. It will be interesting to play against one of the best English teams, who we know well.

‚ÄúThere is no feeling of revenge for us. This is a different competition. This is our pathway and we are used to it.

‚ÄúWe are the champions at the moment in this competition, so the problem is for all the other teams. They have to play against us, that is what I think.‚Äù

Football.title: Historic Scottish football club older than Celtic unveil plans to revamp century-old stadium
Football.content:
A fifth division team in Scotland are reinventing a stadium first used in 1919.

Albion Rovers, a semi-professional team from North Lanarkshire, have planned to transform The Reigart Stadium, also known as Cliftonhill.

3 They played their first ever game in their stadium on Christmas day in 1919 Credit: John Kirkby - The Sun Glasgow

The club‚Äôs Board of Directors have provided an update to move the club into the 21st century.

New facilities include the grass pitch being replaced by an artificial turf which will allow community sports teams to use the grounds.

Director Ben Kearney has said they will install changing facilities specifically for women and girl‚Äôs sports to take place at the venue.

Adding floodlights and an interior to the main stand will make sure the historic ground with sporting significance will be futureproof.

Also known as the Wee Rovers, they are trying to establish themselves as a business before they play in the newly-formed Lowland League West next season.

The club released a statement and director Ben Kearney said: ‚ÄúI‚Äôd like to personally thank all of those involved for the countless hours of free time and expertise that have been afforded to the Project Board.

‚ÄúThe level of interest from our supporters regarding our primary mission has also heartened me.

‚ÄúWe now have Albion Rovers Community Club as part of our family.

‚ÄúThe Community Club is an addition to the work our fantastic Community Trust and Supporters Trust do, and we can now provide strong evidence of the need for a community sports facility at Cliftonhill.‚Äù

The sporting significance of Cliftonhill

Success did not come easy to Albion Rovers, even when they formed in 1882, as they reached six finals in their first nine years and lost them all.

3 The club is six years older than Celtic Credit: John Kirkby - The Sun Glasgow

Albion Rovers created their own talent, with players like Jimmy Conlin - who transferred to Manchester City for ¬£1000 (most expensive football player in the world at the time).

The club made deals with Everton for their player Johnny Mclhatton in 1946, in return for the two teams to play a friendly match at Goodison Park.

The Toffees won 6-3, but nowadays despite the difference in status, the two teams are going through similar transitions of leaving behind tradition and entering new stadiums.

The Wee Rovers have become known for their innovation after a sponsorship deal with Tunnock‚Äôs.

Their shirt appeared to look like a biscuit wrapper after it mimicked the golden wrapper with red diagonal stripes like the ‚ÄòCaramel Wafer Bar‚Äô.

A rivalry with Rangers spread over the course of their history means Cliftonhill‚Äôs highest recorded attendance was against The Gers of 27,381.

3 Albion Rovers took Rangers to a replay in the Scottish Cup 2014 Credit: PA

After taking the highly successful team to a replay in the Scottish Cup in 2014 when Ally McCoist managed the side, it meant the Wee Rovers could play them at home, but they could not use their own ground and instead had to use a local side's stadium, New Douglas Park.

This shows the importance of the upgrades the board have proposed to be able to get the stadium in use.

Who are the Wee Rovers?

Albion Rovers are a football club founded in Coatbridge, Scotland in 1882 and play in the Scottish fifth division, in the Lowland League.

The club have played against many iconic teams such as Celtic and Rangers.

Famous players that have played against the Wee Rovers include Kiernan Tierney, Ryan Christie and Moussa Dembele.

News.title: Dubai attack fears: Is it safe in popular Gulf state in wake of Iran attacks?
News.content:
Dubai attack fears: Is it safe in popular Gulf state in wake of Iran attacks?

Hundreds of thousands of British national in Dubai could be impacted by the wave of retaliation attacks launched by Iran across the Middle East, after it was hit by Israel and the US this morning

View 7 Images Fire near the Burj Khalifa in Dubai (Image: X/@Getta50)

British tourists and expats in the popular Gulf state of Dubai are facing uncertainty and turmoil following a wave of missile attacks across the region today.

‚Äå



Israel and the US launched a joint attack at around 9.30am Tehran time (6am GMT) on the Iranian capital and other cities across the country. Iran has retaliated with a series of strikes on US and Israeli military bases across the Middle East, including in popular tourist nations like the United Arab Emirates and Qatar.

‚Äå



These fraught political tensions have raised questions to the Brits travelling to and living in Dubai - with around 240,000 British nationals believed to be living in the state.

‚Äå



Ensure our latest headlines always appear at the top of your Google Search by making us a Preferred Source. Click here to activate or add us as your Preferred Source in your Google search settings.

Dubai hotel LIVE: Horror as Fairmont Hotel erupts into flames on The Palm READ MORE :

OPINION Chris Hughes America's attack on Iran will be felt for decades to come - by all of us

‚Äå



Brits in the Middle East have been told to shelter while tourists have been plunged into a travel nightmare with flights a Dubai International Airport being halted. The Foreign Office warned Brits to "immediately shelter in place" and urged people to reman indoors and in a secure location. The FCDO also warned British citizens to avoid all travel and follow advice from local authorities as the fallout continues.

View 7 Images Smoke rises after an explosion in Tehran, Iran (Image: AP)

Has Dubai been hit?

Iranian state media said Dubai was one of several places that Tehran has launched an attack on, but they did not reveal what the target of these strikes were. The UAE ministry of defence said it intercepted several Iranian missiles and drones.

‚Äå



Despite this, smoke was seen at the luxury Fairmont Hotel in Dubai, with images from the scene showing the famous hotel on fire. This blaze was reportedly ignited by debris that fell from the sky after a strike.

This luxury hotel, in the state's infamous Palm complex, can be booked through British Airways and TUI. Dubai's Media Office said four people are injured and emergency services have rushed to the scene, with the inferno "under control".

View 7 Images The flare of a projectile seen over the skyline of Dubai on Saturday (Image: AP)

‚Äå



Have people been killed?

One person has reportedly been killed in Abu Dhabi, in the UAE, due to falling debris from a strike this morning. It is not clear which country this victim was from.

In a statement, the Emirati defence ministry said: "The UAE's air defences responded with high efficiency and successfully intercepted a number of the missiles. The relevant authorities also dealt with debris falling on a residential area in Abu Dhabi, resulting in some material damage and the death of an Asian national."

How does this impact British tourists in Dubai?

Thousands of British tourists travel into or through Dubai's two international airports each day, meaning the shocking missile strikes have caused huge disruptions to a massive number of travellers. Several airlines fly from the UK to the popular Middle Eastern state, including British Airways and Wizz Air.

‚Äå



View 7 Images Arrivals board at Gatwick Airport showing a cancelled flight from Dubai (Image: AFP via Getty Images)

A spokesperson for Dubai airports said: "Dubai Airports confirms that all flight operations at Dubai International (DXB) and Dubai World Central ‚Äì Al Maktoum International (DWC) are suspended until further notice. Passengers are advised not to travel to the airport at this time and to contact their respective airlines directly for the latest updates regarding their flights. We appreciate the co-operation of our guests. Further updates will be provided as we continue to monitor the situation."

Emirates airline said: "Due to multiple regional airspace closures, Emirates has temporarily suspended operations to and from Dubai. Emirates urges customers to check their flight status on emirates.com for the latest updates before proceeding to the airport."

‚Äå



What has the Foreign Office said?

The UK government has warned the hundreds of thousands of Brits in Dubai about the risks posed by today's shocking attacks. The FCDO website said: "Due to reported missile attacks, British nationals in UAE should immediately shelter in place.

View 7 Images A projectile falls over Dubai on Saturday (Image: AFP via Getty Images)

"Remain indoors in a secure location, avoid all travel and follow instructions from the local authorities." It added: "There is a heightened risk of regional tension. Escalation could lead to travel disruption and other unanticipated impacts. British nationals should take sensible precautions, considering their own individual circumstances."

‚Äå



The FCDO said this included checking local media, making sure travel documents are up to date and if advised to take shelter to "stay indoors or find the nearest safe building". It added: "An interior stairwell or a room with as few external walls or windows as possible may provide additional protection."

View 7 Images Trump and Israel attacked Iran this morning (Image: AFP via Getty Images)

Is there a terror threat in Dubai?

The Foreign Office advised there was a high threat of terrorist attacks globally, "affecting UK interests and British nationals". It added that "terrorists are likely to try to carry out attacks in the United Arab Emirates".

Article continues below

The FCDO said: "Attacks could be indiscriminate, including in places visited by foreign nationals. Terrorists continue to issue statements threatening to carry out attacks in the Gulf region. These include references to attacks on western interests, including against UK citizens. Due to increasing regional tensions, Israeli and Jewish linked sites could be targets for terrorists in the UAE."

News.title: Donald Trump's unhinged moments you might have missed while we all watched him bomb Iran
News.content:
Donald Trump's unhinged moments you might have missed while we all watched him bomb Iran

While we've all been glued to the carnage unfolding in the Middle East, a number of important and alarming developments from Trumpworld have gone slightly under the radar

View Image On the eve of his historic strikes on Iran, Trump was messing around in a burger joint in Texas (Image: Getty Images)

Donald Trump's attacks on Iran have dominated the news this morning - understandably. But while we've all been glued to the carnage unfolding in the Middle East, a number of important things have gone slightly under the radar.

‚Äå



Things like Trump's allies planning the basis of a coup d'etat. And Pete Hegseth finding the time to pit AI firms against each other to find out which is the least ethical. And the President congratulating a congressman accused of having an affair with an aide, who later died after setting herself on fire.

‚Äå



Here's a few things you might have missed while you were watching Donald Trump blow up Iran.

‚Äå



1. Trump's allies are plotting an 'emergency' to seize control of elections

As we predicted weeks ago, people in Trump's orbit have pulled together a plan to confect a "national emergency" in order to allow Trump's White House to seize control of elections ahead of November's midterms, in which Trump's Republicans are expected to get a pasting. A 17-page draft executive order has been circulated that claims China interfered in the 2020 election. It uses that claim as a basis to declare a 'national emergency', under which Trump could seize more control over voting.

That would include mandatory voter ID across the country as well as banning postal voting. (Remember that Truth Social post a few weeks ago when Trump said Voter ID will be mandatory whether congress votes for it o not?)

Perhaps even more chillingly, the order would force every US voter to re-register, presenting proof of citizenship, in order to cast a ballot in November's midterms.

‚Äå



2. Wait, what? China?

Not only does it claim China rigged the 2020 election, but that it did so on behalf of (check your bingo cards...) Hunter Biden.

Yeah, it's all nonsense. Not a lick of evidence. But that's because...

3. When we say allies...

...the figures so far linked to the draft order include:

‚Äå



Michael Flynn - the former Trump National Security Advisor who served jail time for lying to the FBI about his contact with Russia ahead of Trump's first term

Mike Lindell - the MyPillow guy. Sitting somewhere between a QVC salesman and David Icke, Lindell was the last man standing in Trump's fight to steal the 2020 election. As well as selling bedding for Nazi-dogwhistle prices, Lindell has founded Lindell TV, an online streaming service where he can hawk his favourite conspiracy theories. His "reporters" are frequently called upon for questions at White House events.

Patrick Byrne - the former CEO of Overstock.com and another die-hard election denier. He resigned from Overstock in 2019 after it emerged he'd had an intimate relationship with Maria Butina, a Russian agent.

4. Trump says he knows nothing about it...but...

Trump was asked about this on his way to Texas to give a speech last night. Asked if he was planning to announce a national emergency, he replied: "Who told you that?" Which is one of the answers you least want to hear in response to that question.

He went on to say he knew nothing about it. But then, that's what he said about Project 2025, on which he has based almost his entire policy platform.

‚Äå



5. Trump says he's 'entitled' to one more term

"Time flies," Trump said during his speech at a modestly attended rally in Corpus Christi, Texas last night. "Time flies...maybe we should ...maybe we do one more term. Should we do one more? One more term. Well, we're entitled to it, cos they cheated like hell in the second one. We would actually be entitled to it."

For absolute clarity, he is not entitled to it, and "they" did not cheat in the 2020 election. He lost it to Joe Biden.

Content cannot be displayed without consent

‚Äå



6. 'Loving America' should be mandatory for voting

Andy Burnham would have won the Gorton and Denton by-election, Labour‚Äôs deputy leader has suggested.

Lucy Powell called on her party to draw inspiration from the reasons for Mr Burnham‚Äôs popularity in Greater Manchester, after the devastating defeat on Thursday. Labour fell to third in the vote, with the Greens winning in a constituency the party had held for almost 100 years.

Boxing.title: Conor Benn to face former world champion on same card as Tyson Fury's return to boxing - as first bout since Eddie Hearn split is revealed
Boxing.content:
Conor Benn to face former world champion on same card as Tyson Fury's return to boxing - as first bout since Eddie Hearn split is revealed

Conor Benn is set for a return to the Tottenham Hotspur Stadium after agreeing to share top billing with Tyson Fury and Arslan Makhmudov and fight Regis Prograis in his first outing for new promotion Zuffa Boxing.

The British fighter announced his split with long-time promoter Eddie Hearn last week after 10 years of working together, with Benn instead joining Hearn's rival Dana White's fledgling company in an eight-figure deal.

Hearn revealed that he was 'devastated' by the defection, not least because he stood by the boxing dynasty scion throughout his ordeal over two failed drug tests in 2022.

Benn previously fought in north London when he faced off with Chris Eubank Jr last year, with the fighter gaining his revenge after first being defeated by Eubank Jr in their initial meeting at the stadium.

His match-up with US light welterweight Prograis is set to take place on Saturday April 11, with their main event coming ahead of Fury's return to the ring after his retirement last year.

The evening is also set to be Netflix's first-ever live broadcast, following a number of events shown from the United States - including Anthony Joshua's meeting with Jake Paul last December - by the streaming giant.

Conor Benn will fight Regis Prograis on April 11 on the same card as the returning Tyson Fury

Former world champion Prograis last faced off with Jack Catterall on British soil at the Co-op Live in October 2024, with the Louisiana native losing to the Englishman by unanimous decision.

Benn's decision to desert Hearn cast ripples through the boxing world, with Frank Warren sharing his comment in the form of a quote first made by former US President Harry S. Truman: 'If you want loyalty, get a dog'.

'Conor's not even the best welterweight in Essex,' Warren said bluntly of Benn. 'He's been protected.

'Never fought a contender, never fought for a world title, let alone won one. Forget the two fights with Chris Eubank because I've never rated Junior either.

'So lucky Conor, with all he's been paid so far for such little talent. Even more so with the millions of dollars he's supposed to be getting from UFC boss Dana White as he tries to make it in boxing.'

Daily Mail Sport reported that Hearn is thought to have lent Benn ¬£500,000 following the collapse of his 2022 match-up with Eubank Jr, which came about due to his positive tests.

Hearn also repeatedly defended Benn in public during the lengthy legal battle which followed - only to learn of the end of his relationship with the boxer via email.

'It is very disappointing considering everything I have done for him,' Hearn said. 'Maybe I misjudged his character.'

'I just think the way it was done was very very wrong. But everyone is different. Some people, loyalty really matters, other people maybe not so.



'The way it played out to receive an email from the lawyer and then to ask for a call and not the willingness to have it, you just lose a bit of your soul to it.'

Boxing.title: Manny Pacquiao files bombshell lawsuit after being accused of sending waiter photos of dismembered bodies in 'terror campaign'
Boxing.content:
Manny Pacquiao files bombshell lawsuit after being accused of sending waiter photos of dismembered bodies in 'terror campaign'



Star boxer Manny Pacquiao is suing a top law firm and their client for allegedly fabricating a case against him, falsely accusing him of a ‚Äòterror campaign‚Äô and covering up evidence proving the ‚Äòextortion‚Äô ruse.

Gabriel Rueda, a waiter at celebrity hotspot Craig's restaurant in West Hollywood, sued Pacquiao in 2016 claiming he was owed an $8 million fee for connecting the boxer‚Äôs coach with then-CBS president Leslie Moonves to arrange his blockbuster May 2015 fight against Floyd Mayweather.

Rueda claimed Pacquiao reneged on the deal and terrorized him into submission by texting him photos of dismembered bodies and had his tires slashed, demanding $42 million in damages.

But the case was thrown out last year, with the judge finding no evidence for the claims.

Hitting back with his own lawsuit filed in Los Angeles on Tuesday, Pacquiao says he found a bombshell email allegedly proving the waiter admitted his entire case was baseless just days after it began.

‚ÄòGabriel did it from his heart and asked for nothing in return. No finder's fee, no compensation,‚Äô Rueda allegedly wrote in an email to his publicists at the time.

Manny Pacquiao is suing a law firm and their client for allegedly fabricating a case against him

The message never came to light despite a judge ordering Rueda‚Äôs messages be turned over in 2018, and was only uncovered from a forensic analysis by Pacquiao‚Äôs team in 2023.

Pacquiao‚Äôs lawyers say they traced the gruesome texts of body parts back to a mass-distributed cartel scam.

Records cited by his new lawsuit allegedly show identical threats were sent to more than 100 other people unconnected to the case.

After losing the case, Withers Bergman tried to withdraw as Rueda‚Äôs lawyers, and his attorney Amman Khan‚Äôs profile was removed from the firm‚Äôs website.

Over a decade on from their first encounter, Pacquiao is set for a stunning rematch with Mayweather in Las Vegas later this year.

A Hollywood waiter sued Pacquiao in 2016 after claiming he was owed an $8million fee for helping to arrange his blockbuster May 2015 fight against Floyd Mayweather (pictured)

The fight icons will meet again in September in the first ever boxing match at 'The Sphere' off the strip in Sin City, it was announced earlier this week.

The bout is set to be globally broadcast on Netflix as part of the streamer's growing investment into live sports.

Mayweather, 49, first has to take on Mike Tyson, 59, in an exhibition bout this spring. A date and location has not yet been confirmed.



Meanwhile Pacquiao, 47, has a warm-up fight against Ruslan Provodnikov on April 18, almost a year after his draw with then-WBC welterweight champion Mario Barrios.

Boxing.title: Frank Warren gives verdict on Conor Benn's split from Eddie Hearn - as he refuses to speak on his breakdown in relationship with Saudi backers
Boxing.content:
Frank Warren's lips were legally sealed when he was asked about how the collapse of his fabulously lucrative relationship with boxing's new Saudi paymasters is so cataclysmic that he is taking them to court.

'Can't comment,' he said about suing Their Excellencies.

Although Warren was quick to point out that he will still be promoting 'the biggest shows in boxing' with the likes of the unretired Tyson Fury back in the ring in April and the world heavyweight title fight between shock WBO champion Fabio Wardley and former champ Daniel Dubois the month after.

When it came to Conor Benn's gross betrayal of his long time promoter Eddie Hearn, Warren was revealing on the one hand with but close-chested on the other.

Warren and Hearn were haters for decades but Benn's lamentable dumping for money of the man who nursed him then backed him throughout his drugs allegations clinched their burying of the hatchet.

'I sent Eddie a little note the morning after that,' said Warren. 'I won't tell you exactly what was in it.'

Frank Warren responds to a potential LEGAL BATTLE in boxing ü•äüòß pic.twitter.com/93ohmI9Zkk ‚Äî Daily Mail Sport (@MailSport) February 25, 2026

Frank Warren (right) has given his verdict on Conor Benn splitting from Eddie Hearn (left)

Benn (pictured) ditched Hearn following his victory over Chris Eubank Jr in November

But he did offer a huge clue when he added: 'As former American President Harry S. Truman said, if you want loyalty, get a dog.'

His opinion of Benn was blunt in the extreme: 'Conor's not even the best welterweight in Essex. He's been protected. Never fought a contender, never fought for a world title, let alone won one. Forget the two fights with Chris Eubank because I've never rated Junior either.

'So lucky Conor, with all he's been paid so far for such little talent. Even more so with the millions of dollars he's supposed to be getting from UFC boss Dana White as he tries to make it in boxing.'

Warren was speaking at the London media launch for Wardley versus Dubois in Manchester on April 11. Those two were in good voice.

Wardley astonished the boxing world by coming out of white collar events to become a world champion. To such an extent that when the WBO belt arrived in the post two weeks ago, the inscription of his name on the silver was accompanied by Dave Allen's nickname 'The White Rhino.'

This eloquent pugilist said: 'They sent a replacement without a nickname because I don't have a nickname and don't want one. Fabio Wardley is good enough for me when I'm knocking people out.'

He made it clear, also, that he hand picked another Dynamite puncher in Dubois as his first title challenger 'because I love wars with big hitters which are exciting for the public and for me.'

Dubois expressed thus his hunger to become a two-time world champion: 'Losing my belt to Oleksandr Usyk was like losing a girlfriend, even though it was to the greatest fighter of his generation. Now I'm going to renew that relationship.'

Each believes it will be him adding yet another mighty KO to his record. And they agree this slugfest will not go anywhere near the 12 round distance.

So does Warren. Which is why his promotional title for this fight is 'Don't Blink.'

Boxing.title: Boxing legend Ruben Castillo, who faced some of the biggest names in the sport's history, dies at 68
Boxing.content:
Boxing legend Ruben Castillo, who faced some of the biggest names in the sport's history, dies at 68

Boxer Ruben 'the Conquistador' Castillo has passed away at 68, the World Boxing Council has announced.

A cause of death has not been revealed.

The native Texan and proud Chicano went 69-10-2 over a career that began in 1975 and lasted until 1997. Although he never won a world title, Castillo was a key figure in boxing in the late 1970s and early 1980s, as he battled with some of the biggest names in the sport.

He was 43-0 until he fought the legendary Alexis Arguello in 1980. The bout was competitive, but Arguello scored the 11th-round knockout to retain his WBC super featherweight title.

Castillo would lose his next bout, too, dropping a unanimous decision to Mexican legend Salvador Sanchez after leading the first six rounds.

Castillo later lost to Julio Cesar Chavez in 1985 as the iconic boxer scored a sixth-round knockout at the Forum in Los Angeles.

Ruben Castillo (L) throws a punch against Julio Cesar Chavez during the fight at the LA Forum

Boxer Ruben 'the Conquistador' Castillo has passed away at 68, according to the World Boxing Council. A cause of death has not been revealed

'Excellent contender who was so unfortunate to be in the same era as legendary champs like Salvador Sanchez and Alexis Arguello,' one fan wrote on X. 'Definitely world championship material in a different era. R.I.P.'

Castillo ultimately served as an announcer alongside legendary play-by-play man, Chick Hearn.

'Ruben and Chick Hearn were gold on Fights From The Fabulous Forum broadcasts,' one fan wrote online. 'Great stuff.'

He also had a reputation as a positive influence on many young fighters and fans.

'A great man,' his nephew wrote on Facebook. 'Both him and his family were a great part of my childhood. He always gave great advice, would be there when ya needed him. Going to parties at his place, doing golf charity events. He def was the neighborhood Uncle for alot of us.

Castillo later served as an announcer on many WBC fights from the Forum in Los Angeles

'A Family man, Boxer, Charity planner, we lost. Great one today and too soon. RIP brother hope they got a ring set up so you can box the greats!'

The native of Lubbock, Texas had six children, including twins. A daughter, Misty, preceded him in death. He is survived by his wife, Cindy.

'It is with deep sadness that I have learned of the passing of my dear friend and champion Ruben Castillo,' WBC president Mauricio Sulamain wrote on Instagram.



'Now he is in the arms of God. May his wife Cindy, family and friends find comfort with the support of the so many who loved Ruben. Rest in eternal peace.'

Boxing.title: Driver in horror crash that killed two of Anthony Joshua's close friends appears in court in Nigeria for second time
Boxing.content:
Driver in horror crash that killed two of Anthony Joshua's close friends appears in court in Nigeria for second time

The driver of the car involved in a crash that killed two members of Anthony Joshua's team has appeared in court in Nigeria.

Heavyweight boxer Joshua was travelling in a vehicle near Lagos with his personal trainer Latif Ayodele and strength coach Sina Ghami in December.

Ayodele and Ghami, both 36, were killed when the vehicle collided with a stationary lorry, with Joshua taken to hospital for treatment and later flying home to the UK, where he attended their funerals.

The driver of Joshua's vehicle, Adeniyi Mobolaji Kayode, has been charged with causing death by dangerous driving, reckless and negligent driving, driving without due care and driving without a valid licence.

The 46-year-old appeared at Sagamu Magistrates Court on Wednesday, with his case adjourned to March 13 after prosecutors told the court they needed more time to prepare evidence.

Kayode has yet to enter a plea. He originally appeared in court in January, and did not speak during the hearing. He was previously released from custody after being granted bail of around ¬£2,600.

Anthony Joshua leaving the car after the crash which killed two of his friends in Nigeria

Joshua pictured with Latif Ayodele (left) and Sina Ghami (right)

Driver Adeniyi Mobolaji Kayode leaves court near Lagos after the initial hearing in January

Joshua, 36, paid a heartfelt tribute to his friends after the crash and vowed: 'My goal is to help their families and to help them achieve their goals, even though they may not be here in the physical.

'I will be saying my prayers, and I'm going to help them fulfil their dreams for their families. It's not only me though helping. There's a whole team working on that stuff.

He added: 'There is a whole system that will be helping fulfil their legacy, fulfil their dreams. But I know in my corner of the world, I know what I'm doing, and I know what we're gonna do to continue there.

'I'm gonna do what's right by their family. It's about what's important to me, and they're very important players, very important team, with very important friends and two of my brothers.'



Joshua has also had the names tattooed on his right arm.

Boxing.title: Boxing icons Floyd Mayweather and Manny Pacquiao will fight again in September... 11 years after first showdown
Boxing.content:
Boxing icons Floyd Mayweather and Manny Pacquiao will fight again in September... 11 years after first showdown

Two of the greatest boxers of the 21st Century will face off against each other once again in a long anticipated sequel bout.

Floyd Mayweather and Manny Pacquiao have been confirmed to fight in Las Vegas on September 19 at 'The Sphere' off the strip in Sin City.

The bout is set to be globally broadcast on Netflix as part of the streamer's growing investment into live sports.

This fight has been announced just days after Mayweather indicated his intentions to return to professional boxing after being out of the game since August 2017.

Mayweather, 49, is set to fight against Mike Tyson, 59, in an exhibition bout this spring. A date and location has not yet been confirmed.

Meanwhile Pacquiao, 47, is returning to the ring after losing his senate seat and unsuccessfully running for President of The Philippines in 2022. Pacquiao earned less than seven percent of the vote and lost to current leader Bongbong Marcos.

Floyd Mayweather (L) and Manny Pacquiao (R) will fight again 11 years after their first bout

Mayweather, 49, is set to come out of retirement to fight professionally after his planned exhibition bout against 59-year-old Mike Tyson this spring

Meanwhile, Pacquiao came out of retirement for a professional bout in July 2025

Pacquiao is also set to have a warm-up fight against Ruslan Provodnikov on April 18 at the Thomas & Mack Center in Las Vegas.

The re-match between Mayweather and Pacquiao comes over a decade after they last faced off in 2015.

Mayweather beat Pacquiao by unanimous decision in that fight, which failed to live up to the hype it had received.

This will be Mayweather's first professional fight since 2017, when he defeated Conor McGregor by knockout.

As for Pacquiao, he ended his short four-year retirement last July when he fought then-WBC welterweight champion Mario Barrios to a majority draw.



Particulars of the bout - including weight class and the number of rounds involved - have not yet been released.

Boxing.title: Terrifying moment pro boxer collapses off his stool between rounds and is rushed to Detroit hospital
Boxing.content:
Joseph George is in a 'stable condition' in hospital after collapsing between rounds during a light heavyweight bout with Atif Oberlton.

On Sunday night, George and Oberlton took to the ring as the co-main event to Claressa Shields' eagerly anticipated rematch with Franchon Crews-Dezurn in Detroit.

Oberlton edged the first round of the fight, but things took a drastic turn as the two fighters returned to their corners before the start of the second.

Moments after taking to his stool, George collapsed to the floor, before lying motionless as his team panicked. The cameras were forced to cut away before medics attended to the fighter.

Replays show that late in the first round, the two boxers clashed heads, with George coming away dazed and shaken. It appears this was the reason for his sudden fall to the canvas.

The 36-year-old made it back to his feet following medical attention and was taken to a Detroit hospital to be monitored. Oberlton was then awarded the victory by technical knockout, extending his unbeaten record to 15 wins.

Frightening scenes in Detroit. Light heavyweight Joseph George suffered a head clash in the first round and then collapsed during the break between rounds. üò±



#ShieldsCrewsDezurn2 pic.twitter.com/qH3AMEoDgw ‚Äî Permante (@PermantexG) February 23, 2026

Joseph George had to be rushed to hospital after collapsing during his fight with Atif Oberlton

Hylon Williams, George's trainer, has since confirmed that the fighter is 'undergoing an MRI' and is 'in stable condition at a Detroit hospital'.

Oberlton confirmed that he did get the chance to speak to George as he was escorted out of the ring, but he was 'a bit confused'.

'I'm so glad that he got up on his feet and that he's OK,' said Oberlton. 'I'm a true champion, true warrior. We can do whatever you want to do it, but I'm just happy that he's OK.

'I just wanted to make sure he was safe. At the end of the day, we're warriors, but we want to leave here the same way we come out.'

Later in the night, Shields defended her undisputed heavyweight championship in dominant fashion, dispatching Crews-Dezurn by unanimous decision.

The 30-year-old American won 100-90 on all three judges' scorecards and remains unbeaten in her professional career, with a record of 18 wins.
